title: Quincy Regional Airport
text:
Quincy Regional Airport (Baldwin Field) is a city-owned airport 12 miles east of <a href="Quincy%2C%20Illinois">Quincy</a>, a city in <a href="Adams%20County%2C%20Illinois">Adams County</a>, <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a>, United States. It is used for <a href="general%20aviation">general aviation</a> but also sees <a href="Cape%20Air">Cape Air</a> flights to <a href="O%27Hare%20International%20Airport">O'Hare International Airport</a> and <a href="St.%20Louis%20Lambert%20International%20Airport">St. Louis Lambert International Airport</a>, a service which is subsidized by the federal government's <a href="Essential%20Air%20Service">Essential Air Service</a> program at a cost of $1,956,856 (per year).
The <a href="National%20Plan%20of%20Integrated%20Airport%20Systems">National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems</a> for 2021–2025 <a href="FAA%20airport%20categories">categorized</a> it as a non-primary commercial service airport.
The first airline flights were on Mid-Continent in 1947; successor Braniff left in 1959. TWA arrived in 1948 and left in 1953-54; Ozark arrived in 1950 and left in 1982.
It is the twelfth busiest of the 12 commercial airports in Illinois.
Facilities.
The airport covers 1,101 <a href="acre">acre</a>s (446 <a href="hectare">ha</a>) at an elevation of 769 feet (234 m). It has three runways: 4/22 is 7,098 by 150 feet (2,163 x 46 m) asphalt/concrete; 18/36 is 5,400 by 150 feet (1,646 x 46 m) asphalt/concrete; 13/31 is 5,397 by 150 feet (1,645 x 46 m) asphalt.
For the twelve month period ending January 1, 2019, the airport had 19,444 aircraft operations, an average of 53 per day: 80% <a href="general%20aviation">general aviation</a>, 20% <a href="air%20taxi">air taxi</a> and less than 1% military. In July 2021, there were 54 aircraft based at this airport: 33 single-engine, 7 multi-engine, 13 jet and 1 ultra-light. 
This airport lacks a control tower and operates as an <a href="uncontrolled%20airport">uncontrolled airport</a>.
In celebration of the 2018 Illinois Bicentennial, Quincy Regional Airport was selected as one of the Illinois 200 Great Places by the <a href="American%20Institute%20of%20Architects">American Institute of Architects</a> Illinois component (AIA Illinois).
Airline and destinations.
Passenger.
On November 6, 2006, <a href="Mesa%20Airlines">Mesa Airlines</a> announced that new non-stop service to <a href="Chicago%20Midway%20International%20Airport">Chicago Midway International Airport</a> and <a href="Kirksville%20Regional%20Airport">Kirksville Regional Airport</a> would begin in February 2007 operated by subsidiary <a href="Air%20Midwest">Air Midwest</a>. Nine months after starting the service, Mesa announced they would drop Quincy on November 9, 2007. The airport was formerly served by <a href="Trans%20World%20Express">Trans World Express</a> and <a href="Great%20Lakes%20Airlines">Great Lakes Airlines</a>.
Incidents.
On November 19, 1996, <a href="United%20Express%20Flight%205925">United Express Flight 5925</a> from Chicago via Burlington, Iowa, crashed on landing at Quincy. A <a href="Beechcraft%20King%20Air">Beechcraft King Air</a> was attempting to takeoff on an intersecting runway while the United Express <a href="Beechcraft%201900">Beechcraft 1900</a> landed; the aircraft collided at the runway intersection. All 12 on the B1900 and two on the King Air were killed.
